abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Animal Health
            Services Project for Kenya was unsatisfactory. The project
            did not achieve all of its objectives, it impact on
            institutional development was modest, sustainability is
            unlikely, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower
            was satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, simplification of project design and
            management may not necessarily produce better results, and
            adequate attention should be paid to the overall
            macroeconomic context and the specific ecological and
            socio-economic setting in which the project is to be
            implemented. Second, tse-tse trapping and tick control pilot
            trials were successful because they were participatory and
            demand-driven, and an appropriate institution was assigned
            the task, rather than the trials being handled through the
            public sector. Third, given the promising signs of
            GOK's commitment and support to the privatization
            process with regards to animal health services, future
            projects should aim at supporting efforts in this direction,
            rather than diffusing resources to support a variety of
            activities. Finally, the financial burden imposed on the
            recurrent budget of the Borrower by the maintenance and
            operating costs related to public sector capital investments
            should be evaluated up-front as well as during project implementation.
